summary: This document is an email chain from July 23, 2019, regarding an incident at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with marks on his neck. It details the initial response, medical and psychological assessments, and internal discussions about his placement and cellmate assignment following the incident.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate at MCC New York who was found with red marks on his neck in his cell on July 23, 2019, and placed on suicide watch. He alleged his cellmate attempted to kill him.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Identified as Epstein's cell mate. He is a former police officer pending a death penalty case for murder/triple homicide, arrested in December 2016.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.context: The recipient and sender of emails in the chain, coordinating information about Epstein's status and cellmate assignment.

persons.name: Operations Lieutenant
persons.context: The staff member who initially responded to the assistance call in the Special Housing Unit and found Epstein.

persons.name: Physician Assistant
persons.context: Conducted a medical assessment of Epstein at 6:30 a.m. on July 23, 2019, noting physical findings and Epstein's statements.

persons.name: Psychologist
persons.context: Evaluated Epstein at 9:10 a.m. on July 23, 2019, and determined he should remain on suicide watch.

connections.description: Epstein was cell mates with Tartaglione in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. Epstein alleged Tartaglione attempted to kill him and had been harassing him.
The Associate Warden was responsible for managing Epstein's custody status, cell placement, and reporting on the incident.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Marks in Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell in the Special Housing Unit. He was found lying on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck, unresponsive. He was placed in restraints, moved to a suicide cell, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's Medical Assessment
events.description: At 6:30 a.m., a Physician Assistant examined Epstein. Findings included a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck, but Epstein was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and denied knowledge of how the marks occurred or any pain.

events.title: Epstein's Psychological Assessment
events.description: At 9:10 a.m., a psychologist evaluated Epstein and determined he should remain on suicide watch for further observation.

events.title: Arrest of Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione, Epstein's cell mate, was arrested in December 2016. He is a former police officer accused in a death penalty case for the murder/triple homicide of four individuals who went missing in April 2016.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
Special Housing Unit (SHU), MCC New York
Unit 7 South (general population unit), MCC New York
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with red marks on his neck and alleged his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had attempted to kill him.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident, but during a medical assessment hours later, he was smiling, oriented, and denied knowing how the neck marks occurred.
Epstein's cell mate at the time was Nicholas Tartaglione, a former police officer facing a death penalty case for a 2016 quadruple homicide.
Prison staff were actively reviewing Epstein's case for placement in the general population (Unit 7 South) and seeking an appropriate new cellmate at the time of this correspondence.
The email chain shows internal confusion and a request to draft a clearer summary of events for forwarding to higher authorities (IPPA and the Director).
